subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... There can be no material doubt that they referred originally to the IPA s [A], [O], and [Q] (in the SAMPA transcription of IPA into ASCII), as these are
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> That figuring out is not so simple, as I keep trying to point out. Look
> at the letters #32, #33, and #34. What does Read mean when he uses these
> words to say pronounce the letter like this? I certainly have no idea,
> and from the disagreement I have seen, either does anyone else.

There can be no material doubt that they referred originally to the
IPA's [A], [O], and [Q] (in the SAMPA transcription of IPA into ASCII),
as these are the vowel sounds used in those words in RP English (what
you or someone called "BBC English" earlier). The same is true for any
dialect I know of that has a three-way distinction.

The vowel generally used for all of these in the American West is [A],
the unrounded back low vowel. [Q] is a rounded version of this, and
[O] is also rounded but somewhat higher. The distinction between [A]
and [O] is still preserved before /r/, as is shown by the fact that
Westerners do not pronounce "farce" /fARs/ and "force" /fORs/ the same.

So the question is, do I just put up with it when you write "awed" as
Ah-Day, or do I insist that you artificially learn to write Awe-Day,
which is natural for me and most people outside the U.S. west of the
Missisippi and Canada west of Quebec? That's the policy choice facing
the QS community.

> > It *can* represent all the phonemes, just not all the *sounds*.
>
> But earlier you said that some dialects had more than 40 phonomes, did
> you not, or am I mistaken?

Yes, but I said that that was a relatively unimportant point. If the
letters are made to represent phonemes, most people will use the
same letters in the same words, with a variety of fairly unimportant
exceptions.

But if QS letters mean the same *sounds* everywhere, then instead of
everyone everywhere (near enough) writing At-Key-See-Et-No-Tea for
"accent", we must put up with It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea from New Zealand and
Eight-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea (or even Eight-Utter-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea)
from the Inland Northern U.S. I think that's intolerable.

> Further, you pointed out that the Irish use a different sound to
> pronounce "th". That is a phoneme, not an abstraction. I can not hear
> the difference between the two Irish sounds when I was in Ireland;
> the Irish could. They have phoneme that QS does not recognize.

In Ireland as elsewhere there are two phonemes /d/ and /D/. The former
is pronounced [d] everywhere; the latter is pronounced [D] in most
places but [d<dental>] in Ireland. They have a *sound* that QS does
not represent, if we take QS letters to represent sounds. There is
*no* difference in the phoneme structure.

--

> That figuring out is not so simple, as I keep trying to point out. Look

The vowel generally used for all of these in the American West is [A],

and [O] is still preserved before /r/, as is shown by the fact that

Yes, but I said that that was a relatively unimportant point.  If the

same letters in the same words, with a variety of fairly unimportant

But if QS letters mean the same *sounds* everywhere, then instead of

> Further, you pointed out that the Irish use a different sound to
